Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 4 hours
2-3 hours per week with some weeks exceeding this average depending on upcoming deadlines.
depend on if an assignment is due. about 3-4 hr
5 hours
6 hours on average.
5 h/ week
6 hr/week
on average, 3
Hours spent on work fluctuated-- certain weeks were only 1-2 hours, while others were up to 10 hours per week.

3 hours for weekly readings
6 hours on average for systematic review
I thought the course was excellent and the process of performing a systematic review was a useful skill.

Strengths:
-learned how to write a systematic review
-learned how to read journal articles and see what strengths/weaknesses there are
-really cool speakers

Weaknesses: 
-didn't include readings in class discussion

Enjoyed the guest speakers who came in to the class. It would be nice to incorporate student presentations on individual topics throughout the second half of the semester to break up the usual 2-hour lecture.
very helpful in writing and understanding of obesity prevention status quo. But some of the data and content need to be updated.
This was one of the most interesting classes I have taken thus far at YSPH. I truly enjoyed hearing from guest speakers over the course of the semester as well.
it was useful to learn how to write a systematic review. The format of the class was interesting, with weekly guest lectures.

I really loved the opportunity to write a systematic review from scratch. I felt challenged but thoroughly enjoyed going through the process! I wish the course could be a little more organized. The files on Canvas are not labeled well and it is difficult to find readings or presentations.
An excellent course.

The course went over a diverse methodology of tackling obesity from a clinical and public health standpoint.

I wish there was more group work/round table discussion.

Strengths: very comprehensive introduction of obesity intervention and prevention methods. Guest speakers from different field provide a broad perspective of how to approach similar issues with different solutions.
Weakness: the content is not solid knowledge or not technical enough. Assignment is a systematic review, but we are not really taught how to perform meta-analysis in order to write a proper one. This systematic review is more like a review article, with some logic inside. Course materials need up-to-date statistics, because the data seems not fresh.

Strengths: 
-emphasizes a multitude of perspectives to look at obesity and interventions
-learning how to write a systematic review
-ability to pursue your own interests in the realm of obesity and intervention
Weakness:
-less discussion than I hoped for

This was a very interesting course primarily due to its unique format of lectures, guest speakers, and a systematic review project for students. The systematic review was the course's greatest strength in my opinion. I appreciate that I walk away from the course with a tangible work product and new skill set. My only criticism is that assignment expectations were usually unclear, and I think a rubric would have been useful.

I thought this was a great introduction to obesity and approaches to the obesity epidemic. A strength is that we had wide range of guest lecturers who offered really unique perspectives on obesity that helped me clarify my own opinions and approaches to the disease. I quite liked the class structure, although sometimes the number of students made it difficult to have discussion structured into the class.

I really enjoyed the layout of the course - working up towards a systematic review throughout the course. It was really helpful as I had not ever written a systematic review before. I also really enjoyed hearing from different speakers every so often - it was great hearing different perspectives/approaches.

This course was very enjoyable. Dr. Irwin is incredible at providing timely feedback on assignments. I would be interested in hearing from other fields of work in addition to the three guest speakers we had.

strengths: instructor is very dedicated to the subject and takes all the students together with herself along the course
weakness: bird's eye view of the obesity epidemic
Very good course!

The class is great. It gives a brief introduction on the epidemiology of obesity, and covers various obesity treatments. The instructor brings speakers from different areas working on obesity so we can gain knowledge on how obesity is treated in different settings (i.e. surgery, pharmaceuticals). The class reveals lots of misconceptions on obesity prevalence, nutrition, and physical activity, etc. The systematic review was a great practice on technical writing, and the presentations based on the reviews were informative and was a great learning experience.

This was such a great comprehensive review of approaches to the prevention and treatment of overweight and obesity in the US! Dr. Irwin is such an awesome instructor who keeps it real, and the experts she brought in for guest lectures enriched our learning experience. One of the best parts of the experience was the diversity of students, ranging from MPH to MS to AP and more. I thought I knew a fair share about how to get people to eat better and exercise more, but this course expanded my frontier of knowledge in this area multi-fold. The experience of writing a systematic review was also great, both for people who had never written one before and for the seasoned folks who might actually be able to publish their final product!
great course overall

I thought Dr. Irwin was approachable and available to answer any question I had. She was helpful in spending the time with me to help determine a topic for my systematic review and provided useful feedback. I thought that the course material was relevant to the course topic. I think that linking the reading a little closer to the course lectures may be helpful, but independently I thought that the reading was useful in and of itself.
Prof. Irwin is great! She's so friendly, helpful, and approachable.
AMAZING professor! Provides great and timely feedback on assignments. Great lecturer
Very friendly.
Excellent instructor. Passionate about obesity prevention. Gives constructive feedback. Made the class fun.
Professor Irwin is truly a leader in her field of research and a terrific instructor as well. YSPH and CDE is lucky to have her expertise.
She was nice and well-informed

Loved having Melinda has an instructor! She cares so much about her students and is excited to teach the class. I wish she would give us more guidelines on how to write the systematic reviews or what she expects from our presentations. Sometimes the instructions are very vague and I found it difficult at times to know what is expected.

professor irwin was readily available to help me in her office hours. i visited her office hours almost every week and was always greeted by a positive attitude and constructive criticism on my work. she is inspiring and is passionate about obesity and lifestyle interventions.
An excellent professor.

For each of our assignment, Prof Irwin will provide some feedbacks. However, not many feedback is really  meaningful in a way that will prompt logical thinking or even future thoughts. They are more like - a proof that I have read your assignments. I hope there could be more instructive comments.
Melinda Irwin is an awesome professor and role model when it comes to the field of obesity research. It's motivating that she's so passionate and knowledgeable.
Dr. Irwin is a knowledge and engaging instructor. She presented the material in a clear and fun way.

Dr. Irwin was a great instructor, with enormous expertise in this field. She was ways prepared, timely, and responsive to student feedback. She gave us space to build scientific clarity around obesity, while providing the tools we'd need to do so.
Melinda is an engaging professor - I learned a lot from her in this course and really enjoyed her instruction.

Dr. Irwin is very accessible and more than fair when it comes to grading. I appreciate her passion for the field she works in and her genuine interest in discussion points brought up by students. The only weakness I can think of is that when guest speakers come, her questions are very polite, and I think she let the guest speakers off a little too easily-- for example, the claim by the bariatric surgeon that New Haven does not have a food desert went unquestioned. I think we could have had a really interesting debate on this point, but instead we went back to revisiting different types of surgical methods.
instructor is very dedicated to the subject and takes all the students together with herself along the course
She's great! Thank you for spreading out the systematic review deadlines -- you were 110% right that we would all come to appreciate this during finals.

Dr. Irwin is awesome! She encourages critical thinking and class discussions. She is open to questions and gives helpful feedbacks. She is a good story teller while she is lecturing, and she is also a good listener. She pays attention on the presentations from the speakers and student presentations. She positively takes the ideas from students during class. You can stop by her office whenever you want (if she's there), and receive encouragements and feedbacks from her. She is always enthusiastic!

Dr. Irwin is clearly extremely knowledgable and passionate about lifestyle interventions, particularly for cancer patients. She readily accepts when she doesn't have expertise in an area and is able to pull together sources to give us exposure to multiple approaches to obesity prevention and treatment.
The professor was fantastic. You could tell she is passionate about the topics.

This class teaches about all aspects of obesity: epidemiology and epidemiological trends, complications, and treatment. Concurrently, the course assignments are centered around developing, performing, and writing a report of a systematic review on a topic of your choosing, as well as two editorial on topics related to obesity. I would recommend it as a course for one interested in learning about obesity, and also interested in potentially developing a systematic review manuscript for publication.
Basically how to write a systematic review, with a focus on obesity lifestyle preventions. I'd recommend it if you want to learn how to write a systematic review.

One of the best courses I've taken at YSPH. Would definitely recommend for any student with even the slightest interest in obesity issues. The systematic review is a great opportunity to explore your own personal interests in obesity, and Melinda is a great professor!
Good for comprehensive learning and you'll learn how to conduct a systematic review.
A great course. Please take it!
I would certainly recommend this class to others. Learning how to write a systematic review was such an important skill to gain from the course.
If you want to learn how to write a systematic review, take this course
I would recommend this course! Great experience overall and I learned a lot about obesity in this country.
A good course to know how to write systematic review.
Yes.

If anyone is interested to learn information specifically about obesity, this is a good choice. Otherwise, if your interest is writing a systematic review/ learn about intervention methods, this is not an appropriate one.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who is interested in obesity research. It's a great course that teaches many perspectives of the field.

I highly recommend this course for students interested in a comprehensive take on obesity prevention and lifestyle interventions. We learned everything from gastric bypass surgery to pharmaceutical interventions to policy initiatives for tackling obesity. The systematic review, while perhaps daunting as a whole, was divided into a series of individual assignments and gave the opportunity to learn how to conduct and write up a systematic review from beginning to end.

I'd say it was a comprehensive introduction to obesity as a disease, at various levels of analysis. The major deliverable (a literature review) was a good opportunity to build practical skills while researching a topic of interest relevant to the class, and getting feedback on that review from an expert in the field was invaluable. I would recommend it.
I would (and already have) recommend this class to other students! It is a great elective.

This course is great for learning how to write a systematic review with some guidance, but not too much hand-holding. I would definitely recommend it to another student. The lectures and guest speakers were great, and even though the course is long, it's never boring.
this course gives a bird's eye view of the obesity epidemic and is useful to get a sense to write a systemic review as well. I do recommend a fellow student to consider this course
Fantastic overview of obesity and its causes and health ramifications. If you are at all interested in obesity or diabetes, you MUST take it.

I would highly recommend this class. This class meets all the objectives listed in the syllabus, and promotes critically thinking and professional writing. Obesity is such an epidemic and we all should know something about it. The lifestyle interventions will not only be helpful in obesity intervention, but also other chronic disease. In addition to academic development, this class can make an impact on healthier personal behaviors.

Overall, this is great for anyone with an interest in learning more about the interventions, research and prevention efforts in the realm of obesity. Such a pressing issue and such a great course to be exposed to a broad range of approaches. We wrote two editorials and a systematic review in chunks, so the workload was engaging and manageable. Dr. Irwin is great about providing timely feedback! Overall, would recommend!
would definitely recommend
